action.action-desc: Ms. DeLauro (for herself, Mr. Cicilline, Mr. Grijalva, and Mr. Welch) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Agriculture

form.official-title: To require the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to take certain emergency action to eliminate excessive speculation in energy markets.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Energy Markets Emergency Act
.

paragraph.text: the Commodity Futures Trading Commission was created as an independent agency, in 1974, with a mandate—

subparagraph.text: to protect commodities market users from fraud and abusive trading practices; and
to prevent and prosecute manipulation of the price of any commodity in interstate commerce;

paragraph.text: according to an article published in Forbes magazine on February 27, 2012, excessive oil speculation translates out into a premium for gasoline at the pump of $.56 a gallon based on a recent report from Goldman Sachs;

subparagraph.text: demand for gasoline in the United States was lower than demand was on June 12, 2009;

paragraph.text: excessive oil and gasoline speculation is creating major market disturbances that prevent the market from accurately reflecting the forces of supply and demand; and
the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has a responsibility—

subparagraph.text: to ensure that the price discovery for oil and gasoline accurately reflects the fundamentals of supply and demand; and
to take immediate action to implement strong and meaningful position limits in regulated exchange markets to eliminate excessive oil speculation.

subsection.text: Not later than 14 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission shall use the authority of the Commission (including emergency powers)—

paragraph.text: to curb immediately the role of excessive speculation in any contract market within the jurisdiction of the Commission, on or through which energy futures or swaps are traded; and

to eliminate excessive speculation, price distortion, sudden or unreasonable fluctuations, or unwarranted changes in prices, or other unlawful activity that is causing major market disturbances that prevent the market from accurately reflecting the forces of supply and demand for energy commodities.
